title-group.article-title: The Economic Costs and Transport Benefits of Seoul’s Industrial Land Use Controls

author-notes.corresp: Myung-Jin Jun is in the Department of Urban and Regional Planning, Chung-Ang University, 40-1 Naeri Deduckmyun, Ansung, 456-756, Korea. E-mail: mjjun1@cau.ac.kr.

abstract.p: This study focuses on both the favourable and adverse consequences of Seoul’s industrial development controls; namely, the transport benefits and the economic costs. The study develops a method to estimate the effects of the controls by combining three different models: a 2SLS regression model, a random-utility-based location choice model and a transport model. The most important findings are the aggregate annual economic costs and transport benefits of the controls: a $45.9 billion output and 336 000 job losses versus $4.8 billion in transport cost savings. These empirical findings indicate that the citizens of the Seoul metropolitan region would be better off economically, with more job opportunities, in the absence of the industrial development controls, and would pay relatively minor transport costs for these benefits.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, urban growth controls have pervaded many cities throughout the world. Although the specific objectives, types, intensity and governing bodies of growth regulations vary by nation, metropolitan region and local municipality, these regulations typically aim to mitigate the negative externalities associated with urban growth, such as traffic congestion, urban sprawl and air and water pollution, and to improve a community’s quality of life. On the other hand, critics of growth controls point to the negative consequences, such as discrimination against poorer and minority newcomers (Alonso, 1973) and economic costs. These costs include productivity and job losses (Richardson et al., 1993; Lee and Hong, 2001; Mills and Kim, 1998; and GRI, 2004 and 2007) and rising property values and reduced housing affordability1 (Quigley and Rosenthal, 2005; Quigley and Raphael, 2005; Nelson et al., 2002; Nelson, 2002; Jun, 2006; Son and Kim, 1998; and Segal and Srinivasan, 1985).

Unlike growth controls in the US and Canada, where growth regulations are mostly adopted by the local jurisdictions, many countries in northern Europe and Asia have adopted metropolitan-wide regulatory policies to control growth, mostly imposed by their respective central governments (Mills and Kim, 1998). Along with the common purposes of growth controls, such as less congestion, a cleaner environment and a better quality of life, there are other intended goals for government controls in large metropolitan regions in these countries. One justification is that the government needs to control the growth of large metropolitan regions, because market forces have produced excessively large metropolitan areas, making the metropolitan region overconcentrated and overcrowded. A related justification is that the controls will achieve more balanced national growth by attaining a desirable size distribution of urban areas (Mills, 2002).

It is generally believed that the magnitude of a growth control’s effect is influenced not only by the size of the area controlled by the regulation, but also by the intensity and type of the regulation. For example, metropolitan-wide regulations have much greater impacts than those imposed by a local jurisdiction and the controls on non-residential land use have more serious effects on the urban economy, transport and environment than those on residential land use, ceteris paribus. Interestingly, although multiple studies have examined the effects of urban growth controls, the majority of the impact studies on growth controls focus on the effects on property values and housing affordability caused by residential land use regulations, predominantly focusing on North American cities. Despite the substantial economic, transport and environmental impacts of non-residential land use controls, few studies have examined the effects of non-residential land use regulations.

Richardson et al. (1993) examined the economic and social impacts of residential and non-residential growth controls in Pasadena, California. They found that growth caps on non-residential land generate serious economic losses in terms of output and jobs, particularly hitting the lowest-skilled occupational groups the hardest. Hanushek and Quigley (1990) investigated the fiscal implications of commercial land use controls. Analysing the case of Proposition M, approved by San Francisco voters in 1986, which established an annual cap on new office spaces (950 000 square feet), they argued that, unlike zoning and other residential land use regulations, which generally increase the property values of existing residents, commercial land use regulations generate more complicated impacts, because these controls reduce jobs and, in turn, decrease housing demand and prices, thereby lowering the fiscal capacity of the community.

This study examines the effects of industrial land use controls on the urban economy and transport, using the case of industrial growth controls in the Seoul Metropolitan Region (SMR), the national capital of South Korea.2 To do so, this study employs three analytical models: a two-stage least squares (2SLS) regression model to estimate the size of industrial floor space denied because of the controls; a random-utility-based Seoul metropolitan input–output model (RUSMIO) for estimating the economic costs of the regulations; and, a transport model to estimate the congestion relief benefits and transport cost savings resulting from the controls.

Although the existing studies examining the effects of non-residential growth controls concluded that growth controls have generated significant economic, social and fiscal consequences, these studies focused on the adverse effects of growth controls. In addition, these papers used simpler methods to estimate the effects of growth controls. For example, Richardson et al. (1993) developed a Lowry-type input–output model for a spatial allocation of the impacts of growth controls, while Hanushek and Quigley (1990) borrowed structural models from the existing literature to explain the urban commercial property market.

This paper differs from prior research in several respects. First and most importantly, to the best of the author’s knowledge, no previous study exists regarding the impact assessment of a metropolitan-wide non-residential land use control policy using random-utility-based location choice models built on the random utility theory, which is the most reliable theoretical foundation for state-of-the-art land use models to explain location behaviours of urban actors (Wegener, 2004). Moreover, this paper focuses on both the transport benefits and economic costs of Seoul’s industrial growth control policy. Secondly, another advantage of this study is the development of the method to estimate the effects of the controls as we combined three different models: a 2SLS regression model, a random-utility-based location choice model and a transport model.

This paper is divided into four sections. The first section introduces Seoul’s industrial land use control policies and the controversy between the critics and supporters of these regulations. The second section presents the estimates of the 2SLS regression model and the direct impacts of the controls on manufacturing space supply. The third section explains the model structure of RUSMIO and examines the economic costs of the controls. The fourth section presents the congestion relief benefits and travel cost savings of the controls, followed by the conclusion.

sec.title: Seoul’s Industrial Land Use Controls
sec.p: Korea has a long history of growth control policies imposed on the capital region. Since the early 1960s, when substantial rural-to-urban migration due to rapid industrialisation began, various regulatory policies have been implemented to check the influx of the rural population into the capital region. After a series of such regulatory policies, the first comprehensive legislation was created in 1982 by adopting the Capital Region Management and Planning Law (CRMPL). The CRMPL classified the capital region into five zones and applied different control measures based on the zonal characteristics. In the 1994 amendment, the five zones were merged into three: the Growth Control Zone (GCZ), the Growth Management Zone (GMZ), and the Environment Preservation Zone (EPZ). As shown in Figure 1, the GCZ encompasses the city of Seoul and its neighbouring satellite cities, whereas the northern and southern parts of suburban Seoul were designated as the GMZ. The eastern part of Seoul, which has a superb natural environment with Han River Water Source Preservation Areas, was deemed the EPZ.

caption.p: Seoul’s growth control and management zones.

sec.p: The law regards manufacturing factories as population-inducing facilities and strictly regulates any new construction, expansion and relocation of factories within the SMR using several control measures. First, the Korean government adopted strict growth caps on the SMR’s manufacturing space. The Ministry of Land, Transport and Maritime Affairs (MLTMA) established a three-year industrial growth cap for the entire capital region and allocated the quota to apply to cities and counties after reviewing requests from local municipalities (i.e. the total quota for industrial factories was 12.85 square km during the 2006–08 period). Along with the growth caps on manufacturing space, industrial development is regulated variably by regulation zone, firm size and type of products. While any new construction or expansion of the existing factories owned by large firms3 is strictly prohibited within the entire capital region, the Growth Management Zone and the Growth Control Zone have different size restrictions for factories owned by small and medium-sized firms. For example, unlike the Growth Control Zone, where factories with a size of 1000 square metres or smaller are allowed, the Growth Management Zone does not have size restrictions for factories owned by small and medium-sized firms. A recent amendment introduced a few exceptions, allowing for the entry and expansion of factories owned by large firms within the Growth Control Zone and Growth Management Zone if they produce high-tech products, such as LED TVs and electrical parts.

sec.title: Debate over Seoul’s Industrial Land Use Controls
sec.p: Since their implementation, the growth controls on the SMR have been a source of controversy. Advocates of the regulations insist that growth controls on the SMR have contributed to mitigating the SMR’s overconcentration by diverting manufacturing firms from the SMR to non-capital regions. For example, Ko (2001) surveyed 49 factories that moved from the SMR to adjacent non-capital regions (Chung-Cheong province) with a questionnaire inquiring as to the reason for relocation and found that approximately 60 per cent of the surveyed firms answered that the industrial land use regulations in the SMR were the main reason for relocation. In addition, Song (1997) argued that growth control policies in the SMR made a significant contribution to the reduction of serious traffic congestion and pollution, and helped to relieve the housing shortage problem.

On the other hand, opponents of growth control argue that the regulations on the SMR are not successful in achieving the intended objective, which is to reduce the SMR’s concentration, arguing that both population size and the proportion of population of the capital region have substantially increased during the past four decades, in spite of the strict regulations. According to the Korea National Statistical Office (KNSO), the SMR’s population has increased by 4.4 times over the past 45 years, from 5.2 million in 1960 to 22.8 million in 2005. Furthermore, the share of the SMR’s national population has significantly increased, from 20.8 per cent to 48.2 per cent during the same period, indicating that almost half of the Korean population lives in the capital region. Critics also insist that the regulations undermine national and local economic competitiveness, because the regulations do not divert the manufacturing firms to the non-capital regions; rather, they drive the firms to foreign countries, mainly China and south-east Asia (Son, 1997; Hur, 1998 and 2003). Others analyse the loss of productivity as the cost of the growth controls (Mills and Kim, 1998), providing empirical evidence of a reduction in manufacturing productivity in the presence of growth controls (Lee and Hong, 2001; GRI, 2004 and 2007). Another serious side effect of the land use controls is the increase in property values and transport costs, due to the limited urban land supply. Considerable evidence exists that demonstrates the rise in land and housing prices ((Hannah et al., 1993, and Son and Kim, 1998) and the increase in transport costs (Jun and Bae, 2000; Jun and Hur, 2001; and Bae and Jun, 2003), caused by the greenbelts in the SMR, which limit both residential and non-residential land supply.

Given the divided arguments in the existing literature over the effects of Seoul’s growth controls, this study examines two important factors in Seoul’s industrial land use controls: the economic costs and the transport benefits. We used three analytical models: a 2SLS regression model, a random-utility-based Seoul metropolitan input–output model (RUSMIO) and a transport model.

sec.title: Estimating the Economic and Transport Impacts of Seoul’s Industrial Land Use Controls
Overview of Analysis Procedures
sec.p: As shown in Figure 2, estimating the economic and transport impacts of the industrial land use controls requires several steps. The first task was to build a 2SLS regression model in order to estimate the manufacturing space denied because of the controls. The prohibited manufacturing space was converted into a monetary value (value-added) and used as input data for the RUSMIO. For the second task, the RUSMIO model projected the locations of production, residence and shopping and generated three types of activity flow based on the random utility choice theory: a commodity flow, a commuting flow and a shopping flow by industry (income group for household) and zone. When the RUSMIO located these activities, it used travel time matrices (SKIMs) as input data obtained from trip assignments (see equations (A3), (A10) and (A13) in the Appendix). The RUSMIO also generated output ($), jobs and resident workers by zone for the baseline (with regulations) and non-regulation scenarios. The differences in output and jobs signify the economic costs of Seoul’s industrial land use regulations.

caption.p: Flow chart to estimate the economic and transport impacts of industrial land use controls (equation numbers in parenthesis).

sec.p: Estimating the transport effects of Seoul’s industrial growth controls also required several steps. First, personal trips (commuting and shopping flows) in the baseline and non-regulation scenarios, derived from the RUSMIO, were converted into daily vehicle trips4 by mode using the probability of mode m, the average vehicle ridership (AVR) and the passenger car unit (PCU).5 This study did not convert commodity flows into truck trips, because no survey data are available for this conversion. However, because the 2002 Household Travel Survey (HTS) includes truck trips, truck trips were loaded on the network. Secondly, the daily vehicle trips were divided into peak hour6 and off-peak hour7 vehicle trips, using the time of day analysis. Therefore, four vehicle O–D matrices were loaded into the network: peak and off-peak hours for the baseline and non-regulation scenarios. Mode choice probability, average vehicle ridership and hourly distribution of daily trips by mode were taken from the Household Travel Survey. Thirdly, using the average travel times during peak and off-peak hours derived from the trip assignments, the annual person-trip hours were estimated and converted into annual transport costs using the of travel time value.

sec.title: Estimation of Industrial Floor Space Denied because of the Controls
sec.p: The first analytical approach was to estimate the size of the industrial floor space prohibited because of the controls. Since Seoul’s industrial land use regulations started three decades ago and different types of regulative measure of varying intensity were imposed on different areas within the SMR, it is almost impossible to measure the cumulative size of the manufacturing space prohibited from development. Therefore, this study takes a simpler but statistically sound method: a 2SLS regression model was used to estimate the supplies of industrial floor space with and without the controls. This study employed a 2SLS method, rather than a multiple regression, in order to account for the causal relationships between manufacturing floor space and manufacturing employment. In other words, manufacturing employment is a key variable in determining the supply of manufacturing floor space; yet, manufacturing space supply affects manufacturing employment. The data sources for the model include the Mining and Manufacturing Census (KNSO, 2003), the Census of Establishments and Business Enterprises (KNSO, 2003) and other socioeconomic databases from the Korea National Statistical Office (KNSO). All of the datasets were collected by dong, the smallest administrative boundary in Korea, with the exception of a variable called ‘land size planned for urban use’, which was collected by city (or county), because of a lack of data availability in dong. As shown in Table 1, the average population size per dong is about 15 000 persons. The dataset included 2409 observations (dongs).

caption.p: Basic statistics for the continuous variables of the 2SLS model

tr.td: Land area planned for urban use (square km)a
Proportion of agricultural land to total land
Proportion of residential land to total land
Proportion of employees in floor-space-intensive industries to total employees

sec.p: The 2SLS model has the following mathematical forms

where, F = the manufacturing space supplied; E = the manufacturing employees; PI = the proportion of employees in floor-space-intensive industries to the total number of employees; PR = the industrial floor space productivity; L = the land size planned for urban uses; R = the proportion of residential land to total land; A = the proportion of agricultural land to total land; D = the distance to Seoul’s downtown; C = the activity centre dummy; GC = the growth control area dummy variable; GM = the growth management area dummy variable; POP = the population size; RD = the road length; WC = the proximity to the West Coast Expressway; and SB = the proximity to the Seoul–Busan Expressway.

The first equation is a manufacturing space supply equation in which the amount of space supplied is a function of the manufacturing employment, land use and location-related variables, and regulation-related variables. The second equation arises because manufacturing employment is a function of the manufacturing space supplied and other control variables, such as population size and accessibility variables. The dependent variable in the first equation is simply the natural log of the manufacturing space supplied in 2003. Ten independent variables were used for the model, including four manufacturing space demand-related variables: the number of manufacturing employees, the proportion of employees in floor-space-intensive industries to the total number of employees, the floor space productivity (output/floor space) as a proxy for the price of manufacturing space and an activity centre dummy variable.

Since the supply of manufacturing space is believed to be highly related to the existing land uses, the model included four land use and location-related variables: total land size planned for urban uses, proportions of residential and agricultural land to total land size and distance to Seoul’s CBD. Finally, two regulation-related variables were included: dummy variables for the Growth Control Zone (GCZ) and Growth Management Zone (GMZ). We did not include a dummy variable for the Environment Preservation Zone (EPZ), because the EPZ should be protected from development in order to preserve the natural environment and Han River fresh water basin.

The manufacturing employment equation has six explanatory variables. The model included population size, because the number of people employed is likely to have a positive correlation to population size. Included were four location and accessibility-related variables believed to affect employment size: the natural log of road length, including freeways and major arterial roads passing through the administrative boundary; two dummy variables representing the proximity to major expressways, the Seoul–Busan Expressway and the West Coast Expressway8 (1 if expressways pass through a city (or county) where the zone is located, 0 otherwise); and the distance to Seoul’s downtown.

Since two land use control dummy variables (GC and GM in equation (1)) represent the impact of controls on manufacturing space supply, the supply of industrial floor space expected in the absence of the controls was estimated by removing the two dummy variables from the model. The direct impact of Seoul’s industrial land use controls were estimated by comparing the manufacturing space supply in the SMR, assuming the existence of the industrial regulations (baseline), with the manufacturing space that could have been supplied without the regulations (non-regulation scenario).

Table 1 shows the basic statistics for the variables used in the regression model and Table 2 reports the results of the 2SLS regression model run. The overall performances of the first and second equations were relatively good, with R2 values of 0.54 and 0.34 respectively and all of the variables in both equations showed the expected signs with statistical significance at the 1 per cent level. For the manufacturing space supply equation, the number of manufacturing workers had the strongest power in explaining the supply of manufacturing space with the highest t-value. A higher concentration of workers in the space-consuming industries necessitated more manufacturing space, and a higher proportion of agricultural land was positively related to manufacturing space supply, indicating a high conversion rate of agricultural land to industrial land in agricultural-land-rich areas.

caption.p: 2SLS estimate for predicting supply of manufacturing floor space (N = 2409)

tr.td: Proportion of employees in floor-space-intensive industries to total employees
Log(land size planned for urban use)
Proportion of residential land to total land
Proportion of agricultural land to total land
Activity centre dummy (1 if a zone is anactivity centre, 0 otherwise)
Growth control area dummy (1 if a zoneis located within the GCA, 0 otherwise)
Growth management area dummy (1 if a zoneis located within the GMA, 0 otherwise)
Proximity to West Coast Expressway(1 if West Coast Express way passes througha city (county) where the zone is located, 0 otherwise)
Proximity to Seoul–Busan Expressway(1 if Seoul–Busan Express way passes through a city (county) where the zone is located, 0 otherwise)

sec.p: Conversely, a high productivity of manufacturing space (higher price), larger areas of land reserved for urban uses in general and residential land (with a higher proportion of residential land) and urban activity centres showed a negative relationship with manufacturing space supply. Most importantly, two regulation-related dummy variables had a negative sign, with statistical significance at the 1 per cent level. These findings provide empirical evidence that, after controlling other variables which might affect the supply of manufacturing space, Seoul’s industrial land use controls have been effective in restricting manufacturing space supply.

For the manufacturing employment equation, as expected, the population size and road length (a proxy for accessibility) were positively related to manufacturing employment, while the distance to Seoul’s CBD negatively correlated with manufacturing employment, indicating a high concentration of industrial factories in the Seoul metropolitan area. Interestingly, closer proximity to the Seoul–Busan Expressway was positively related to manufacturing employment, whereas proximity to the West Coast Expressway showed a negative relationship with manufacturing employment size, implying that more industrial firms are located near the Seoul–Busan Expressway, which connects the largest and second-largest cities of Korea (Seoul and Busan), than in west coast region, where the West Coast Expressway passes through.

Table 3 shows the estimated manufacturing space of the baseline and non-regulation scenarios by sub-region. The baseline is the estimated value from the regression model, including dummy variables, and was adjusted by the actual total manufacturing space of the SMR, while the floor space of the non-regulation scenario was estimated using the regression model after removing the land use control dummy variables. In 2003, approximately 7.7 square km of manufacturing space was prohibited by the land use controls in the SMR. About half of the manufacturing space prohibited would have located in the Kyunggi Province, if Seoul’s industrial land use controls had never been adopted, indicating that the Kyunggi Province has been affected the most by regulation effects in terms of denied manufacturing space.

caption.p: Direct impact of Seoul’s industrial land use controls in terms of manufacturing space (unit: ‘000 square metres)

sec.p: Both manufacturing spaces of the baseline and non-regulation scenarios were converted into value-added in monetary terms, using a conversion factor of value added per square metre. The difference in value-added between the baseline and non-regulation scenarios was added to the baseline final demand from the Bank of Korea (2007) in order to make input data (final demand) for the RUSMIO in the non-regulation scenario.

sec.title: Economic Impacts of Seoul’s Industrial Land Use Controls
sec.p: For the analysis of the economic impacts of the industrial land use regulations, we employed a random-utility-based metropolitan input–output model for the SMR (the RUSMIO). The RUSMIO is an upgraded version of the existing Seoul metropolitan input–output model (Jun, 2004, 2005, 2009 and 2011) that adopts the random utility theory as its theoretical foundation to explain spatial choice behaviour9 and combines it with a transport model capable of measuring the congestion effects of urban policy and planning (for a more detailed specification of the model, refer to Jun, 2011). The RUSMIO consists of three location choice modules (production, residence and shopping). Further specifications of the RUSMIO are presented in the Appendix.

The RUSMIO consists of 16 industrial sectors, 3 income groups for households and 23 land use zones (LUZ).10 The primary data source for the building of the RUSMIO is the 2003 multiregional input–output transaction table (Bank of Korea, 2007) and the Household Travel Survey for the SMR. Since the RUSMIO is a constrained non-linear model, this study used GAMS CONOPT Solver in order to determine the optimal solution for the non-linear simultaneous equations.11 As shown in Table 4, the RUSMIO’s simultaneous equation system has 13 638 equations and 13 638 variables: 8464 equations for the production location choice module (16 x 23 x 23), 1587 equations for the residential location choice module (3 x 23 x 23), 1587 equations for the shopping location choice module (3 x 23 x 23), and 2000 equations for internal data conversions (such as converting workers by occupation into households by income group).

tr.td: The total production of commoditym in zone i
The total demand (consumption) ofcommodity m in zone j
The deterministic utility of purchasingone unit of commodity n from zonei to zone j
Flow of sector m from zone i to zone j
The average cost of input n in zone j
The price of producing a unit ofcommodity n in zone i
Workers of sector m in zone i
Workers of income group h in zone i
Commuting trip of income group hfrom work zone i to home zone j

Households by income group hand zone j
Daily shopping trips of incomegroup h from home zonei to shopping zone j
Deterministic utility of choosingshopping locationof income group h

fn.label: a
fn.p: Number of zones (23), sectors (16) and income groups (3) in parenthesis.

sec.p: Although the RUSMIO generates various economic impacts by sector, zone and income group, this paper presents the sectoral and spatial consequences of the controls in terms of output and jobs. We only considered output flows from the manufacturing activities prohibited as the economic impacts, ignoring output from construction activities denied by the controls, because the economic impacts from the construction activities are incurred only during the construction period. Therefore, Tables 5 and 6 report the annual output and job losses because of the controls, estimated using 2003 data and monetary values. The Korean currency, the Won, was converted into the US dollar at a rate of $1:1000 Won.

Table 5 shows the output impacts of the regulations by industry. The overall output loss due to the industrial land use controls was $45.9 billion, which was 5.9 per cent of the SMR’s total output in 2003. Interestingly, electric and electronic products experienced the biggest output losses, with more than $11 billion lost output. Textiles and apparel also had relatively large output losses. As expected, the output losses of the service sectors were not significant, since the growth controls were imposed on the manufacturing industries.

caption.p: Output impacts of Seoul’s industrial site regulation by sector (unit: $million)

tr.td: Wood, paper and printing and publication

sec.p: Table 6 presents job losses by zone. The SMR lost approximately 336 000 jobs because of the controls, or 4.6 per cent of the total jobs in 2003. About 45 per cent of the job losses took place in the city of Seoul and in Kyunggi Province, roughly 150 000 jobs, while the city of Incheon lost approximately 37 000 jobs in 2003. The biggest job losses occurred in the zones of Seoul, in which about 20 000 jobs were gone because of the controls, while many zones in Kyunggi Province lost 12 000–18 000 jobs each. The analysis results indicate that the advantages of these areas for industrial development have not been utilised because of the industrial land use controls. Interestingly, the outlying zones in the SMR, such as Pocheon, Icheon and Gapyung, have been impacted much less, with under 6000 job losses.

caption.p: Job impacts of Seoul’s industrial site controls

sec.title: Transport Impacts of Seoul’s Industrial Land Use Controls
sec.p: As explained in the previous section, the hourly vehicle trips at peak and off-peak times were assigned to the transport network of the SMR. This study used the SMR’s network12 with 123 TAZs, 22 049 links and 7292 nodes, obtained from the Gyunggi Research Institute (GRI). O–D flows by land use zone (LUZ), produced by the RUSMIO, were disaggregated into O–D flows by transport analysis zone (TAZ), using a conversion matrix between LUZ and TAZ that was derived from the Household Travel Survey. Four trip assignments were made using TransCad software: peak and off-peak hour traffic for the baseline and non-regulation scenarios. User equilibriums were reached after the 103rd and 114th iterations of the baseline and non-regulation scenarios during peak hours and after the 18th and 21st iterations during off-peak hours respectively.

Table 7 shows the summary results of the trip assignments. Seoul’s industrial land use regulations have contributed to a reduction of approximately 98 000 vehicles during peak hours and 41 000 vehicles during off-peak hours, on average. The congestion relief effects of the regulations during peak hours are considerable, decreasing the average travel time from 33.63 to 30.57 minutes and increasing the average travel speed from 21.4 km/hr to 23.4 km/hr. However, the transport benefits of the regulations during off-peak hours are insignificant, with a reduction in the average travel time of only 0.20 minutes.

caption.p: Transport benefits of Seoul’s industrial land use controls

sec.p: In order to estimate the annual transport cost savings of Seoul’s industrial land use controls, two sets of ratios have been computed from the Household Travel Survey data: proportions of peak and off-peak trips by purpose; and proportions of modes chosen by trip purpose. This study does not include personal trips made by walking/biking or subway when computing the travel cost savings, because these trips are not affected by traffic congestion. For example, the survey data show that about 22 per cent of commuters and 33 per cent of shoppers choose walking/biking or the subway. The yearly aggregated passenger travel time was computed as follows: the number of persons who travel on network*average travel time (hour)*2 (round trip) * 300 (days). Furthermore, the yearly travel costs were computed by multiplying the yearly person-hour travel time by the value of time. This study used $15.68/hour for work- or business-related trips and $5.13 for shopping or other trips (school, personal and recreational trips) as the value of time, obtained from the Korea Transport Institute (KTI, 2007).

Table 8 presents the yearly aggregate person-travel time and travel cost for the baseline and non-regulation scenarios. In 2003, the total travel cost savings of Seoul’s industrial growth controls was about $4.8 billion. Commuters travelling during peak hours were the biggest beneficiaries in terms of travel cost savings, with a reduction of approximately 55 per cent in the total transport cost. Another beneficiary group was the traveller making business-related trips, including truck drivers, with $1.2 billion in cost savings. The transport cost savings for shopping and other trips were insignificant because of the low value of time and relatively high proportion of trips made during off-peak hours.

caption.p: Transport cost savings of Seoul’s industrial growth regulations

fn.label: a
fn.p: Number of person trips x (average travel time/60) x 2 (round trip) x 300 days.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Apply $15.68/hour for work- and business-related trips, and $5.13 for shopping and other trips as the time value, which comes from KTI (2007).

sec.p: The transport benefit analysis of the controls shows relatively minor travel cost savings ($4.8 billion) relative to the economic costs and job losses ($46 billion and 336 000 jobs). There are two explanations for this. The first relates to the SMR’s extensive public transit system. The second is the high density and mixed land use development that comprises almost 60 per cent of the trips using public transit and non-motorised modes, such as walking and biking (according to the 2002 HTS, the public transit share was 40 per cent, while the walking/biking share was 19.1 per cent).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the debate over the effects of growth controls, supporters of the regulations emphasise the favourable consequences of controlled growth, overlooking the adverse effects of growth controls; critics take the opposite position. This study has focused on both the positive and negative consequences of Seoul’s industrial development controls—the transport benefits and the economic costs respectively.

Among several findings worthy of note, the most important are the aggregate annual economic costs and transport benefits of the controls: $45.9 billion output and 336 000 job losses vs $4.8 billion in transport cost savings. These empirical findings imply that the Korean government incurs significant economic costs for the realisation of relatively minor transport benefits. Some might argue against this conclusion by pointing to the environmental benefits flowing from the industrial growth controls, particularly emphasising the effects of the controls on keeping out manufacturing factories, which are the major stationary sources of urban air and water pollution. However, the findings from this study do not support such an argument, because approximately 40 per cent of the output losses take place in the electric and electronic products, machinery products and transport equipment sectors, which are known as more technology-intensive and cleaner industries in terms of pollution than other manufacturing industries. In addition, it is difficult to find substantial vehicle kilometres of travel (VKT) reduction effects as a result of the regulation, which is a good indicator for measuring mobile source emissions, because the difference in average travel distances between the baseline and non-regulation scenarios is not significant.

The findings of this research present important policy implications. Although this study did not consider all of the possible consequences of the growth controls, the conclusion to be drawn is that the citizens of the SMR would be better off economically, with more job opportunities, in the absence of the industrial development controls and would pay relatively minor transport costs for these benefits. The findings of this paper hardly support the position of growth control advocates who submit that Seoul’s industrial growth controls are an effective policy tool for congestion relief. However, caution is required in regard to a generalisation of these findings, because transport benefits might vary significantly by metropolitan area depending on the level of automobile dependence, development density and land use patterns. For example, urban areas with a high share of drive-alone and experience of suburban gridlock might enjoy greater transport benefits than the SMR from the growth controls. Another caution is needed when interpreting the economic costs and transport benefits because the model could not take the environmental and amenity effects of the controls into account.

The current version of the model can be improved for better assessments of the effects of the growth controls. More comprehensive assessments can be possible by introducing modules to estimate the environmental and amenity effects of the controls, one of key intended benefits of growth controls. Another model improvement could further disaggregate land use zones. The improved model would have the capability of measuring more comprehensive and detailed effects of growth controls in terms of the type of consequences and the geographical units.

sec.title: The Random-Utility-Based Seoul Metropolitan Input-Output Model (RUSMIO)
sec.p: The RUSMIO has three components: production, residence and shopping location choice modules.

sec.title: Production location choice module
sec.p: The production location choice module determines the production location by sector and estimates trade flow using random utility concepts, given the final demand by sector and zone exogenously. The following mathematical equations present the production location choice module

where,
x
ij
m
= the flow of sector m from zone i to zone j;
a
j
mn
= amount of production of sector n demanded by a unit of sector m in zone j;
X
i
m
= the total production of commodity m in zone i;
D
j
m
= the total demand (consumption) of commodity m in zone j;
FD
j
m
= the final demand for sector m’s output in zone j;
p
i
n
= the price of producing a unit of commodity n in zone i;
d
ij
n
= the cost to transport a unit of commodity n from zone i to j; λn = a dispersion parameter for commodity n;
v
ij
n
= the deterministic utility of purchasing one unit of commodity n from zone i to zone j; and
c
j
n
= the average cost of input n in zone j.

Equations (A1) and (A2) represent the typical Isard’s trade flow and multiregional input–output structure, while equation (A4) adopts the random utility theory in estimating trade flows. Equation (A3) presents a deterministic utility function, which consists of the costs of production and transportation. Equation (A5) shows that the average cost of the input commodity is computed by the weighted average of the purchase prices and transport costs, whereas equation (A6) represents the sales price of a commodity produced by sector n in zone j. The production location choice module determines the production location choices of firms and generates output and trade flows by sector and zone.

sec.title: Residential location choice module
sec.p: The residential location choice module has the following mathematical forms

where,
E
i
m
= the workers of sector m in zone i;
X
i
m
= the output of sector m in zone i;
e
i
m
= the workers per dollar of output of sector m in zone i;
O
i
h
= the workers of income group h in zone i;
inc
i
h
= the conversion matrix from workers by industry to workers by income group in zone i;
JWH
ij
h
= the commuting trips of income group h from work zone i to home zone j;
μ
ij
h
= the deterministic utility of choosing residential location of income group h;
ha
j
h
= the zonal attractiveness for residential location of income group h in zone j;
d
ij
h
= the commuting cost of income group h from zone i to j; and σh = the dispersion parameter for income group h.

Since the production location choice module generates output by sector and by zone, the output can be easily converted into employment, using the number of workers per dollar of output, as shown in equation (A7). Equation (A8) converts the workers by industry into workers by income group using a conversion matrix. Equation (A9) allocates the workers by place of work into residential locations, generating commuting flows by income groups, based on the utility function in equation (A10).

sec.title: Shopping location choice module
sec.p: The shopping location choice module has the following mathematical forms

where,
H
j
h
= the households of income group h in zone j;
JHS
ij
h
= the daily shopping trips of income group h from the home zone i to the shopping zone j;
sf
i
h
= the number of shopping trips per household of income group h in zone i;
η
ij
h
= the deterministic utility of choosing shopping locations of income group h;
sa
j
h
= the zonal attractiveness for shopping for income group h in zone j;
d
ij
h
the shopping costs of income group h from zone i to j; and φh = the dispersion parameter for income group h.

Since we know where households reside, from the residential location choice module, the shopping destinations were determined based on the utility function in equation (A13), which consists of shopping attractiveness and transport costs. Equation (A12) distributes the total production of shopping trips made by income group h in zone i over shopping zones, generating shopping flows by income group.

sec.title: Transportation Model
sec.p: The transportation mode has two components: mode choice and trip assignment.

sec.title: Mode choice
sec.p: Given the three types of O–D flows (commodity flows, commuting flows and shopping flows) generated by the random utility based input–output model, the transportation model estimates the vehicle trips from these flows using the multinomial logit (MNL) model. The MNL model computes the probability that a person chooses a given alternative from a set of alternatives to the utility of these alternatives, as follows

where,
T
ij
m
= trips from zone i to zone j by mode m; Pm = probability of taking mode m; and Vm = the measurable components of the utility of mode m, which consists of individual characteristics and modal attributes, such as travel time and costs.

sec.title: Trip assignment
sec.p: After factoring hourly vehicle O–D trips from the mode choice, hourly vehicle trips are assigned on the network. This paper employs the user equilibrium (UE) method, which takes an iterative process to achieve a convergent solution, where no travellers can improve their travel times by shifting routes. In each iteration network, the link flows are computed, which incorporate the link capacity restraint effects and flow-dependent travel times. The link capacity restraint method is used to change the impedance of a link as the assigned traffic on it increases, and represents the impact congestion has on route choice and trip assignment (NHI, 1994). The network parameter, time, is adjusted link by link according to user-specified volume/capacity time adjustment curve data or the standard Bureau of Public Roads capacity restraint formula as follows

where,
T
i
0
= the free-flow travel time on link i; and Ti = the travel time for the assigned volume on link i; Ci = the capacity of link i; Vi = the volume on link i; and α, β = the parameters.

fn.p: Most literature focuses on housing or land price effects and housing affordability issues stemming from growth controls. Refer to review papers, such as Quigley and Rosenthal (2005) for the housing price effects and Nelson et al. (2002) for the housing affordability effects.

The Seoul Metropolitan Area consists of three distinct but functionally related spatial units: the city of Seoul, the city of Incheon and Kyunggi Province. The size of the SMA is 11 700 square km and the total population is about 22.8 million, as of 2005.
A manufacturing firm with more than 300 permanent employees.

According to the 2002 Household Travel Survey, 51 per cent of the total daily personal trips are commuting (38 per cent) and shopping (13 per cent) trips. This study uses other personal trips, such as business and recreational trips, from the survey data for the baseline, controlling the total daily personal trips. For the non-regulation scenario, other trips are adjusted using ratios in employment and resident workers between the baseline and non-regulation scenarios, assuming that employees or households in the absence of industrial growth controls would have the same travel patterns.
The AVRs for automobile, taxi and bus are 1.3, 1.7 and 16.5; PCU for bus is 2.5.
The a.m. peak is from 7:00–9:00, and p.m. peak is from 18:00–20:00.
Opened in 2001, the West Coast Expressway runs through the major western regions of South Korea with a total length of 353 km.
Wegener (2004) reviewed 20 state-of-the-art land use models and found that 19 of them rely on the random utility or discrete choice theory to explain spatial choice behaviour.
Seven zones in Seoul, 13 zones in Kyunggi and 3 zones in Incheon.
The original network from the GRI (2002) has 1132 TAZs. This revision has been made in order to reduce the gap between LUZ and TAZ, because the RUSMIO has 23 land use zones (LUZ).
This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
